title: What is a liberal arts degree? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Liberal Arts include the following four categories: Humanities - English Literature, History, Philosophy, Religion, Ethics, Foreign Languages (modern and classical), and SpeechSocial Sciences - Anthropology, Economics, Geography, Political Science, Sociology, Archaeology, Communication Studies, History, Jurisprudence, Linguistics, Political Science, Psychology, Gender Studies, and Public HealthCreative Arts - Fine Art, Theatre, Speech, Music, and Creative WritingNatural Sciences – Astronomy, Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, and PhysicsThere was a time in the US when you could get a great job if you earned a bachelor’s degree in “anything.”  The catch is that JFK was president at the time. College in America doesn’t work that way anymore. Thomas B Walsh's answer to What has changed about being a college student over the last 25 years?  I’m going to let you in on a secret. Back in the day, almost nobody went to college, but if you did go and graduated, prospective employers assumed you were smart. Today, given that college has been watered down and everybody and his brother goes, when you graduate, you have to prove you are smart. You do that by building a compelling resume. Your major is one important element in that resume. Experiential learning is another. Thomas B Walsh's answer to As college degrees become the norm, they no longer distinguish potential employees. What does? Notes What Can You Do with a Liberal Arts Degree? Plenty, With the Right Skills | Burning Glass Technologies Underemployment: The Long-Term Impact on Careers A Couple Anecdotes: Ragin' Cajuns I was in Dallas to see the Buckeyes win the national football championship in January 2015. Coming home through DFW I stopped to grab a BBQ sandwich before my flight, and joined in a conversation with a couple recent graduates of the University of Louisiana Lafayette—Ragin’ Cajuns. One was behind the counter doling out brisket, chips, and beer, and the other was a customer catching a plane to his new energy sector job in Houston. This is just one example of how decisions on post-secondary education today can have widely disparate outcomes. Today, with an army of teenagers matriculating, your major and your resume matters—A LOT. The Rose Bowl Two weeks before graduation, I was sitting in the main library on the Oval reading the sports page of the Columbus Dispatch. (I’m pretty sure this was the first time I had ever darkened the door of the library.) The story I was reading was about the upcoming Rose Bowl between the Wisconsin Badgers and the USC Trojans. The lower right hand page contained a quarter page ad for a leading computer manufacturer. (This company was the Google of the day.) I didn’t have a job lined up. I didn’t have a clue what I was going to do come January 2, the day after the Rose Bowl. So, what the heck, I answered the ad, and, lo and behold, was invited to interview. I don’t remember how they contacted me, since I didn’t have a phone. I borrowed a tie from my boss at the Student Union bowling alley. One of my roommates lent me his car, a battered Ford. I spent a pleasant day at my prospective employer’s office in a small Ohio city. Late in the afternoon the branch manager asked me, “Would you like to be a systems engineer, or would you like to be a salesman?” A penniless college student, the idea of living on commission scared me senseless. So, I said, “It’s pretty obvious I don’t want to be a salesman. I’ll do that other thing.” As I was on the way out the door heading back to Columbus, the branch manager called out, “Buy a suit.” I don’t know this for a fact, but I might have been the only one who applied for that job. That was the beginning of my thirty-six year career in Information Technology. That was the 1963 Rose Bowl. USC won. PS I didn’t have a resume when I went to that interview. If I had prepared one, it would have been one line: BA Philosophy The Ohio State University Today that resume would land me a job at New Lex Hardware and Supply in my hometown.
